Moreover, the utility of the non-base-flipping mechanism employed by these enzymes to recognize SCPCHD adducts has not been explored outside YTM and AlkD. To elucidate how YtkR2 and C10R5 evolved to efficiently eliminate lesions generated by diverse SCPCHD natural products, we performed a comparative biochemical, biophysical, and structural analysis to identify differences between AlkD and these specialized homologs that are responsible for conferring enhanced cellular resistance against YTM,
anns.postfix: , and DSA.

and C10R5 evolved to provide self-resistance against YTM and CC-1065 YtkR2 and C10R5 evolved to provide self-resistance against YTM and CC-1065 YtkR2 and C10R5 evolved to provide self-resistance against YTM and CC-1065 Historically, bulky DNA lesions, such as SCPCHD adducts, have been regarded as substrates for the NER pathway51–54.

anns.prefix: However, we previously showed that NER provides Bacillus anthracis with only limited resistance against YTM, while
anns.postfix: BER provides a modest degree of additional resistance18.

anns.prefix: At the time, we speculated the
anns.postfix: homologs that evolved in antibiotic-producing bacteria would provide greater resistance against their SCPCHD natural products.

anns.prefix: To test this theory, we transformed Escherichia coli with either an empty plasmid or a plasmid encoding
anns.postfix: , YtkR2, or C10R5, and incubated the cultures with various concentrations of YTM, DSA, or CC-1065 (Supplementary Fig. 3).

anns.prefix: In cultures containing YTM, only
anns.postfix: provided clear and significant resistance, shortening the lag phase before exponential growth.

anns.prefix: Similarly, in cultures containing CC-1065, C10R5 provided the greatest resistance, although
anns.postfix: , and to a much lesser extent AlkD, also provided additional resistance.

anns.prefix: Similarly, in cultures containing CC-1065, C10R5 provided the greatest resistance, although YtkR2, and to a much lesser extent
anns.postfix: , also provided additional resistance.

anns.prefix: The same trend was observed in cultures containing DSA; C10R5 provided the greatest resistance, followed by
anns.postfix: and then AlkD. These data are consistent with the notion that YtkR2 and C10R5 evolved to provide self-resistance against YTM and CC-1065, respectively.

anns.prefix: We previously demonstrated that slow multiple turnover by
anns.postfix: was correlated with inhibition of AP endonuclease activity in vitro, which we attributed to tight binding of the AP product generated upon base excision18,57.

anns.prefix: The substantially faster multiple turnover that we observed with
anns.postfix: and C10R5 therefore suggests that product affinity is weaker for these homologs.

anns.postfix: , AP-DNA generated by YtkR2 or C10R5 was incised by EndoIV to a substantially greater extent, regardless of which SCPCHD adduct was excised to produce the abasic site, consistent with relatively weak product binding by YtkR2 and C10R5.

anns.prefix: To explain the structural basis for cellular resistance against SCPCHD compounds provided by
anns.postfix: and C10R5, the AlkD product complexes were used as templates to create homology models of both homologs bound to abasic DNA and each of the nucleobase adducts (Supplementary Fig. 9).

anns.prefix: To explain the structural basis for cellular resistance against SCPCHD compounds provided by YtkR2 and C10R5, the
anns.postfix: product complexes were used as templates to create homology models of both homologs bound to abasic DNA and each of the nucleobase adducts (Supplementary Fig. 9).

anns.prefix: Despite the low sequence identity (19–25%) among the three proteins, the only putative structural difference of note is an extended loop between helices αI and αJ in both
anns.postfix: and C10R5.

anns.prefix: The three homologs appear to share the same three catalytic residues and a high conservation among DNA-binding residues, although
anns.postfix: and C10R5 possess fewer apparent DNA-binding residues (15 and 14, respectively) than the 18 present in AlkD. Within the substrate-binding cleft, the largest variation predicted by the homology models is in the residues that contact the SCPCHD adducts.

anns.prefix: The three homologs appear to share the same three catalytic residues and a high conservation among DNA-binding residues, although YtkR2 and C10R5 possess fewer apparent DNA-binding residues (15 and 14, respectively) than the 18 present in
anns.postfix: the substrate-binding cleft, the largest variation predicted by the homology models is in the residues that contact the SCPCHD adducts.

anns.prefix: However, despite this variation,
anns.postfix: and C10R5 seemingly form few specific interactions with any of the adducts, including the adduct that each evolved to excise.

anns.prefix: The only putative hydrogen-bonding interactions between
anns.postfix: and YTM are formed between Arg42 and the hydroxyl and methoxy substituents of the S−1 subunit.

anns.prefix: Surprisingly, all of the adduct-binding residues in
anns.postfix: and C10R5 that appear to be specific for YTM and CC-1065 are equivalent to the three DNA-binding residues in AlkD that form similar interactions with YTM-Ade and CC1065-Ade (Fig. 5c and Supplementary Fig. 9).

anns.prefix: Surprisingly, all of the adduct-binding residues in YtkR2 and C10R5 that appear to be specific for YTM and CC-1065 are equivalent to the three DNA-binding residues in
anns.postfix: that form similar interactions with YTM-Ade and CC1065-Ade (Fig. 5c and Supplementary Fig. 9).

anns.prefix: As with
anns.postfix: , the remainder of the binding interactions are composed of water-mediated hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic contacts, and CH-π interactions.

anns.prefix: This apparent lack of structural specificity, combined with the nearly complete lack of specificity observed in the excision assays, suggests the enhanced cellular resistance provided by
anns.postfix: and C10R5 does not result from enhanced recognition of a particular SCPCHD adduct.

anns.prefix: Instead, the additional cellular resistance provided by
anns.postfix: and C10R5 seems more likely to result from decreased product affinity, which may be explained, at least in part, by the reduced number of predicted DNA-binding residues in these homologs (Supplementary Fig. 9).

anns.prefix: Discussion Discussion In our experiments,
anns.postfix: and C10R5 provided the greatest cellular resistance to YTM and CC-1065 toxicity, respectively, consistent with evolution of these proteins within the context of the biosynthetic gene cluster for each natural product.

also provided significant resistance against CC-1065, which was somewhat unexpected because of the presence of the unique S+2 subunit, and suggests that interactions with this subunit do not play an important role in determining substrate specificity.

anns.prefix: Despite selective pressure for
anns.postfix: and C10R5 to provide self-resistance against YTM and CC-1065, neither homolog evolved to remove YTM-Ade or CC1065-Ade adducts at a substantially increased rate, as observed by the strong correlation between multiple-turnover excision and cellular resistance.

anns.prefix: We previously showed that
anns.postfix: ’s low level of protection against YTM results from product inhibition in which the enzyme remains bound to the newly formed abasic site in the DNA, slowing multiple-turnover excision, as well as impeding subsequent repair steps in the BER pathway18.

anns.prefix: Both
anns.postfix: and C10R5 have evolved to circumvent this inhibition, while also minimizing their impediment to later repair steps.

anns.prefix: It is interesting to speculate that the evolution of
anns.postfix: and C10R5 to improve multiple turnover occurred as a means to handle the high concentration of YTM or CC-1065 in the producing strains, whereas the rapid single-turnover activity of AlkD is sufficient to provide resistance to the presumably much lower intracellular quantities of these compounds in Bacillus and other non-producing bacteria.

anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: /C10R5 enzymes belong to one of two known bacterial DNA glycosylase superfamilies that have evolved a non-base-flipping mechanism as a means to remove structurally diverse duplex-stabilizing adducts18,43,45.

anns.prefix: The AlkD/
anns.postfix: enzymes belong to one of two known bacterial DNA glycosylase superfamilies that have evolved a non-base-flipping mechanism as a means to remove structurally diverse duplex-stabilizing adducts18,43,45.

anns.prefix: An unrelated DNA glycosylase,
anns.postfix: , from Streptomyces sahachiroi was recently found from its association with the biosynthetic gene cluster for azinomycin B, a highly toxic interstrand crosslinking agent, and shown to provide self-resistance through unhooking of the corresponding DNA crosslinks27,60.

anns.prefix: Enzymes in the
anns.postfix: superfamily have since been shown to remove a variety of alkylated DNA adducts and interstrand crosslinks27,61,62.

anns.prefix: Despite their different polypeptide folds,
anns.postfix: and AlkD family enzymes adopt a similar C-shaped DNA-binding architecture that enables access to the target N-glycosidic bond while the aberrant nucleotide remains stacked in the DNA.

anns.prefix: The yatakemycin biosynthesis cluster in Streptomyces sp. TP-A0356 contains an AlkD-related DNA glycosylase, YtkR2, that serves as a

anns.prefix: The yatakemycin biosynthesis cluster in Streptomyces sp. TP-A0356 contains an AlkD-related DNA glycosylase, YtkR2, that serves as a self-resistance mechanism against yatakemycin
We previously reported that AlkD, which is not present in an SCPCHD producer, provides only limited
anns.postfix: against yatakemycin.

anns.prefix: We now show that YtkR2 and C10R5, a previously uncharacterized homolog found in the CC-1065 biosynthetic gene cluster of Streptomyces zelensis, confer far greater
anns.postfix: against their respective SCPCHD natural products.

anns.prefix: We previously showed that AlkD’s low level of protection against YTM results from product
anns.postfix: in which the enzyme remains bound to the newly formed abasic site in the DNA, slowing multiple-turnover excision, as well as impeding subsequent repair steps in the BER pathway18.

anns.prefix: Both YtkR2 and C10R5 have evolved to circumvent this
anns.postfix: , while also minimizing their impediment to later repair steps.

anns.prefix: Reduced product
anns.postfix: may be explained by the fewer DNA-binding residues predicted in these proteins, which are also the only contacts predicted to form “specific” hydrogen bonds with the adducts.
